entry.title: nce3-03
entry.content:
An unknown goddess

Listen to the tape then answer the question below.

How did the archaeologists know that the statue was a goddess?

Some time ago, an interesting discovery was made by archaeologists on the Aegean island of Kea.

An American team explored a temple which stands in an ancient city on the promontory of Ayia Irini.

The city at one time must have been prosperous, for it enjoyed a high level of civilization.

Housesâ€”often three storeys highâ€”were built of stone.

They had large rooms with beautifully decorated walls.

The city was even equipped with a drainage system, for a great many clay pipes were found beneath the narrow streets.

The temple which the archaeologists explored was used as a place of worship from the fifteenth century B.C. until Roman times.

In the most sacred room of the temple, clay fragments of fifteen statues were found.

Each of these represented a goddess and had, at one time, been painted.

The body of one statue was found among remains dating from the fifteenth century B.C.

Its missing head happened to be among remains of the fifth century B.C.

This head must have been found in Classical times and carefully preserved.

It was very old and precious even then.

When the archaeologists reconstructed the fragments, they were amazed to find that the goddess turned out to be a very modern-looking woman.

She stood three feet high and her hands rested on her hips.

She was wearing a full-length skirt which swept the ground.

Despite her great age, she was very graceful indeed, but, so far, the archaeologists have been unable to discover her identity.

entry.title: nce3-02
entry.content:
Thirteen equals one

Listen to the tape then answer the question below.

Was the vicar pleased that the clock was striking? Why?

Our vicar is always raising money for one cause or another, but he has never managed to get enough money to have the church clock repaired.

The big clock which used to strike the hours day and night was damaged many years ago and has been silent ever since.

One night, however, our vicar woke up with a start: the clock was striking the hours!

Looking at his watch, he saw that it was one oâ€™clock, but the bell struck thirteen times before it stopped.

Armed with a torch, the vicar went up into the clock tower to see what was going on.

In the torchlight, he caught sight of a figure whom he immediately recognized as Bill Wilkins, our local grocer.

â€˜Whatever are you doing up here Bill?â€™ asked the vicar in surprise.

â€˜Iâ€™m trying to repair the bell,â€™ answered Bill. â€˜Iâ€™ve been coming up here night after night for weeks now. You see, I was hoping to give you a surprise.â€™

â€˜You certainly did give me a surprise!â€™ said the vicar. â€˜Youâ€™ve probably woken up everyone in the village as well. Still, Iâ€™m glad the bell is working again.â€™

â€˜Thatâ€™s the trouble, vicar,â€™ answered Bill. â€˜Itâ€™s working all right, but Iâ€™m afraid that at one oâ€™clock it will strike thirteen times and thereâ€™s nothing I can do about it.â€™

â€˜Weâ€™ll get used to that, Bill,â€™ said the vicar. â€˜Thirteen is not as good as one, but itâ€™s better than nothing. Now letâ€™s go downstairs and have a cup of tea.â€™

entry.title: nce3-01
entry.content:
A puma at large

Listen to the tape then answer the question below.

Where must the puma have come from?

Pumas are large, cat-like animals | which are found in America.

When reports came into London Zoo | that a wild puma had been spotted forty-five miles south of London, they were not taken seriously.

However, as the evidence began to accumulate, experts from the Zoo | felt obliged to investigate, for the descriptions | given by people who claimed to have seen the puma | were extraordinarily similar.

The hunt for the puma began in a small village | where a woman | picking blackberries | saw â€˜a large catâ€™ | only five yards away from her.

It immediately ran away | when she saw it, and experts confirmed | that a puma will not attack a human being | unless it is cornered.

The search proved difficult, for the puma was often observed | at one place in the morning | and at another place | twenty miles away in the evening.

Wherever it went, it left behind it | a trail of dead deer | and small animals like rabbits.

Paw prints were seen | in a number of places | and puma fur was found clinging to bushes.

Several people complained | of â€˜cat-like noisesâ€™ at night | and a businessman | on a fishing trip | saw the puma up a tree.

The experts were now fully convinced | that the animal was a puma, but where had it come from?

As no pumas had been reported | missing from any zoo | in the country, this one must have been | in the possession | of a private collector | and somehow managed to escape.

The hunt went on | for several weeks, but the puma was not caught.

It is disturbing to think | that a dangerous wild animal | is still at large | in the quiet countryside.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯æˆ‘ä¸å¿…å‘Šè¨´ä½ ï¼Œç¶²ä¸Šè³¼ç‰©æ˜¯ä¸€ä»¶å¤§äº‹ï¼Œåœ¨ç¾åœ‹å’Œåœ¨ä¸–ç•Œè¨±å¤šå…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹ä¸€æ¨£ã€‚2021å¹´ï¼Œç¾åœ‹æ¶ˆè²»è€…åœ¨ç¶²ä¸Šå•†å‹™ä¸­èŠ±è²»äº†8700å„„ç¾å…ƒã€‚è€Œè¿‘å¹´ä¾†ï¼Œç•¶é€™äº›è³¼ç‰©è€…é€²å…¥çµè³¬é é¢æ™‚ï¼Œä»–å€‘é–‹å§‹æ³¨æ„åˆ°ä¸€ç¨®æ–°çš„æ”¯ä»˜é¸é …ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯æ‰€è¬‚çš„ "å…ˆè²·å¾Œä»˜"ã€‚

03:02-03:40

The option is offered by new companies with names like Klarna, Afterpay, and Affirm. It works like this. Consumers can buy a product for, say, $200. But instead of paying $200 upfront, they can split it into four monthly payments of $50 eachâ€”and pay no interest.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯è©²é¸é …ç”±æ–°å…¬å¸æä¾›ï¼Œåç¨±ç‚ºKlarnaã€Afterpayå’ŒAffirmã€‚å®ƒçš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†æ˜¯é€™æ¨£çš„ã€‚æ¶ˆè²»è€…å¯ä»¥è³¼è²·ä¸€å€‹ç”¢å“ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚200ç¾å…ƒã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œä»–å€‘å¯ä»¥æŠŠå®ƒåˆ†æˆå››å€‹æœˆæ”¯ä»˜ï¼Œæ¯å€‹æœˆæ”¯ä»˜50ç¾å…ƒï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯é ä»˜200ç¾å…ƒï¼Œè€Œä¸”ä¸ä»˜ä»»ä½•åˆ©æ¯ã€‚

03:40-04:25

These companies market themselves as a friendly way to pay. Their names, web sites, colors, marketing, and messaging are all bright, positive, upbeat, fresh, friendly, and modernâ€”a contrast to the stuffy, restrictive, rules-laden world of banks and traditional credit cards. And this new payment option is a hit with Generation Z.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯é€™äº›å…¬å¸æŠŠè‡ªå·±æ¨éŠ·ç‚ºä¸€ç¨®å‹å¥½çš„æ”¯ä»˜æ–¹å¼ã€‚ä»–å€‘çš„åç¨±ã€ç¶²ç«™ã€é¡è‰²ã€ç‡ŸéŠ·å’Œä¿¡æ¯å‚³ééƒ½æ˜¯æ˜äº®ã€ç©æ¥µã€æ¨‚è§€ã€æ–°é®®ã€å‹å¥½å’Œç¾ä»£çš„ï¼Œé€™èˆ‡éŠ€è¡Œå’Œå‚³çµ±ä¿¡ç”¨å¡çš„ä¿å®ˆçš„ã€é™åˆ¶æ€§ã€å……æ»¿è¦å‰‡çš„å¢ƒæ³å½¢æˆäº†é®®æ˜çš„å°æ¯”ã€‚é€™ç¨®æ–°çš„æ”¯ä»˜æ–¹å¼åœ¨Zä¸–ä»£ä¸­å¾ˆå—æ­¡è¿ã€‚

04:26-05:07

Consumers like buy now, pay later for a few reasons. The first one is obvious: get what you want today and pay less for it. To date , credit cards have been the primary way a consumer can get something today and pay for it tomorrow. But not everyone can get a credit card. To get a credit card here, you need a credit history (and need to be) in the United States.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯æ¶ˆè²»è€…å–œæ­¡å…ˆè²·å¾Œä»˜ï¼Œæœ‰å¹¾å€‹åŸå› ã€‚ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹åŸå› å¾ˆæ˜é¡¯ï¼šä»Šå¤©å¾—åˆ°ä½ æƒ³è¦çš„æ±è¥¿ï¼Œä¸¦ç‚ºä¹‹æ”¯ä»˜è¼ƒå°‘çš„è²»ç”¨ã€‚è¿„ä»Šç‚ºæ­¢ï¼Œä¿¡ç”¨å¡ä¸€ç›´æ˜¯æ¶ˆè²»è€…ä»Šå¤©å¾—åˆ°æ±è¥¿ï¼Œæ˜å¤©å†ä»˜æ¬¾çš„ä¸»è¦æ–¹å¼ã€‚ä½†ä¸æ˜¯æ¯å€‹äººéƒ½èƒ½ç²å¾—ä¿¡ç”¨å¡ã€‚è¦åœ¨é€™è£¡ç²å¾—ä¸€å¼µä¿¡ç”¨å¡ï¼Œä½ éœ€è¦åœ¨ç¾åœ‹æœ‰ä¿¡ç”¨è¨˜éŒ„ï¼ˆä¸¦ä¸”éœ€è¦ï¼‰ã€‚

05:08-05:50

But over 53 million Americans donâ€™t have a credit score, so they canâ€™t even get a credit card. And people whoâ€™ve recently immigrated might have the credit history, just not in the right country. Buy now, pay later companies do analyze the potential buyer, but they donâ€™t rely on traditional credit scores. That allows them to offer credit to shoppers that canâ€™t get a credit card.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯ä½†è¶…é5300è¬ç¾åœ‹äººæ²’æœ‰ä¿¡ç”¨åˆ†æ•¸ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä»–å€‘ç”šè‡³ç„¡æ³•ç²å¾—ä¿¡ç”¨å¡ã€‚è€Œæœ€è¿‘ç§»æ°‘çš„äººå¯èƒ½æœ‰ä¿¡ç”¨è¨˜éŒ„ï¼Œåªæ˜¯æ²’æœ‰åœ¨åˆé©çš„åœ‹å®¶ã€‚å…ˆè²·å¾Œä»˜çš„å…¬å¸ç¢ºå¯¦åˆ†æäº†æ½›åœ¨çš„è²·å®¶ï¼Œä½†ä»–å€‘ä¸¦ä¸ä¾è³´å‚³çµ±çš„ä¿¡ç”¨è©•åˆ†ã€‚é€™ä½¿ä»–å€‘èƒ½å¤ å‘ç„¡æ³•ç²å¾—ä¿¡ç”¨å¡çš„è³¼ç‰©è€…æä¾›ä¿¡è²¸ã€‚

05:51-06:23

In fact, this is the exact reason this payment became popular in the United States. Paying in installments is common in some parts of the world, especially in Brazil and other parts of Latin America. But it hadnâ€™t ever caught on in the United States, where consumers preferred credit cards.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯äº‹å¯¦ä¸Šï¼Œé€™æ­£æ˜¯é€™ç¨®ä»˜æ¬¾æ–¹å¼åœ¨ç¾åœ‹é–‹å§‹æµè¡Œçš„åŸå› ã€‚åˆ†æœŸä»˜æ¬¾åœ¨ä¸–ç•Œä¸€äº›åœ°æ–¹å¾ˆæ™®éï¼Œç‰¹åˆ¥æ˜¯åœ¨å·´è¥¿å’Œæ‹‰ä¸ç¾æ´²å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹ã€‚ä½†å®ƒåœ¨ç¾åœ‹ä¸€ç›´æ²’æœ‰æµè¡Œèµ·ä¾†ï¼Œç¾åœ‹çš„æ¶ˆè²»è€…æ›´å–œæ­¡ä¿¡ç”¨å¡ã€‚

06:24-07:10

Then Walmart realized that many of its customers wanted to pay for their items over time, but they didnâ€™t qualify for credit cardsâ€”they didnâ€™t even qualify for the Walmart store card. So Walmart partnered with Affirm, a startup, to let shoppers pay in installments. And it worked. Suddenly, other stores, especially online stores, realized that if this was working for Walmart, it could work for them, too.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯ç„¶å¾Œï¼Œæ²ƒçˆ¾ç‘ªæ„è­˜åˆ°ï¼Œè¨±å¤šé¡§å®¢æƒ³åœ¨ä¸€æ®µæ™‚é–“å…§æ”¯ä»˜ä»–å€‘çš„å•†å“ï¼Œä½†ä»–å€‘æ²’æœ‰è³‡æ ¼ä½¿ç”¨ä¿¡ç”¨å¡ï¼Œä»–å€‘ç”šè‡³æ²’æœ‰è³‡æ ¼ä½¿ç”¨æ²ƒçˆ¾ç‘ªå•†åº—å¡ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ²ƒçˆ¾ç‘ªèˆ‡ä¸€å®¶å‰µæ¥­å…¬å¸Affirmåˆä½œï¼Œè®“è³¼ç‰©è€…ä»¥åˆ†æœŸä»˜æ¬¾æ–¹å¼ä»˜æ¬¾ã€‚é€™å¾ˆæœ‰æ•ˆã€‚çªç„¶é–“ï¼Œå…¶ä»–å•†åº—ï¼Œç‰¹åˆ¥æ˜¯ç¶²ä¸Šå•†åº—æ„è­˜åˆ°ï¼Œå¦‚æœé€™å°æ²ƒçˆ¾ç‘ªæœ‰æ•ˆï¼Œå°ä»–å€‘ä¹Ÿå¯èƒ½æœ‰æ•ˆã€‚

timeline

While it started by catering to consumers who couldnâ€™t get credit, the idea has gone mainstream. Now, many consumers who do have credit cards still prefer buy now, pay later. They think itâ€™s easier to manage than credit card debt. With credit cards, you have to pay the full balance at the end of every month; if you donâ€™t, you start paying interest. If you canâ€™t pay the full amount, a lump-sum balance rolls forward from month to month. And for consumers that carry credit card balances, thereâ€™s no end in sightâ€”thereâ€™s no term to a credit card loan, it just seems to go on forever .

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

But with buy now, pay later, a $200 purchase spread over four monthly payments has a beginning and an end, and no interest. And if consumers pay on time, there are no fees either.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

Waitâ€”no fees? So how do these companies make money? The answer is they charge the retailer, usually three percent of the total purchase. And why do retailers pay the charge? Three reasons: cart abandonment, average order size, and order frequency.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

Consumers often put items in their online shopping cart, and then get to the checkout page and, for whatever reason, they donâ€™t order. This is called cart abandonment, and it has many causes. It could be password issues . It could be that having to enter a credit card makes them think twice . Or it could be that the price is just too high.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

But if, say , a $200 item only requires a $50 payment today, and if you donâ€™t even need to enter a credit card number, well, that sounds more reasonable. And more consumers continue with the purchase rather than abandon the cartâ€”and the store makes their money.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

There are two other reasons retailers like buy now, pay later: average order size and order frequency. Afterpay is one of the buy now, pay later firms. They have a special page where they explain their service to retailers, and on that page they cite two compelling statistics. First, shoppers who use Afterpay spend 40 percent more per order. And those same shoppers complete 50 percent more transactions.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

Retailers, then, are all too happy to pay the three percent fee these companies charge because they know that with this option, their customers will buy more, and buy more often.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

So whatâ€™s not to like? SFGate is a web site based in San Francisco, where many of these buy now, pay later companies are based. And SFGate found that Generation Z is spiraling into debt by using buy now, pay later.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

timeline

On Mondayâ€™s lesson, Iâ€™ll tell you what that investigation found, and why itâ€™s worrying.

æ­£é«”ç¿»è­¯to be update

Credit challenges

timeline

I will say this, itâ€™s not easy to establish a credit history and credit score if you just move here from another country. And there are so many advantages to having a credit card, even if you donâ€™t use it to borrow, and those are not available to people without a credit score. So I do appreciate that buy now, pay later can help someone spread out payments for something big, like a flight or a new appliance or something. But, as weâ€™ll see next week, a lot of people are buying everyday things this wayâ€¦and Iâ€™d think twice about doing that. Speaking of whichâ€¦
